F. has been engaged in her business for 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. F. joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. F. is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP with which she will purchase more fish to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by F. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

location.town: Tuyabang Alto Oroquieta City Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam P., 41, is a resident of Kompong Cham Province. She is married to Keit Rin, 43, who is a farmer, and they have four children. Three of her daughters work in the garment industry as sewing workers. 

She is a rice farmer who plants rice crops on her farmland. In addition, she also sells items such as sweets, vegetables, meat, cooked ingredients, soft drinks, and other inventory in her wooden kiosk. She earns an average of $2.5 a day. 

Sam P. is requesting a Kiva loan to buy some wooden poles for replacing the broken floor and to pay for mending costs.

loans.use: to buy some wooden poles for replacing the broken floor and to pay for mending costs.

loans.name: Rosset

texts.en:
Rosset is a hardworking single mother of two children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda, and longing to build a permanent residential house.  

She is a tailor and also sells clothes for a living.  With the income generated, she has been able to provide for her family.  She has a challenge of limited capital to meet the ever-changing tastes of her customers and her desire is to own a boutique.  Rosset needs the loan to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en: Lourdes H. is from the village of San Vicente, Tambulig Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 30 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns and operates a business selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,050 PHP a month from these activities. In 2011, Lourdes joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like soft drinks, sugar and rice to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lourdes from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She has been engaged in her business for seven years and earns approximately $112 a month for these activities. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP with which she will purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. texts.en: Peter is a forty-three-year-old married man with eight children, living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after the family, and his desire is to educate his children. He has been in the transport sector for four years, and he got his initial capital from farming. He has a challenge because of the current financial crisis, which has led to an increase in fuel prices. His desire is to have three motorcycles. Peter needs the loan to buy a motorcycle.

Alice is 27 years old and is married with two children, 2 and 3 years old. Alice has four years' experience and she employees one person to help her. 

Alice has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more bananas to sell. With the additional profits from this, Alice plans to buy a field and build a comfortable house.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson J. is from the village of Libertad, Aurora Zambonga Del Sir. He is 52 years old. Nelson is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Nelson owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing waste management services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating tricycle transport services. Nelson has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Nelson joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelson is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nelson from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Twezimbe Ganda Development Group

texts.en: N. Dorothy is 30 years old. She has run a food sales business for the past two years in Ganda, Kampala. The happily married mother of two says she was inspired by a close friend to try her hand at this business. Before that, Dorothy was mostly preoccupying herself with household chores. She sells a variety of foods such as bananas, cassava, beans, rice and cabbage at Ganda food market. She says her weekly profits are to the tune of 30,000 UGX. With this loan, she is going to purchase more crops such as rice, sweet potatoes and peas for resale.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda C. is from the village of Lintugop, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 38 years old, married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising fish for sale. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2011, Rosalinda joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase nursing fry/fingerling to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 39 years old, married and has seven family members (two of them are working). In 2010, Jawad bought a large generator to distribute power lines to the people. He has good experience because he was working for many years in this field. He has a good reputation and is well known in his area.

Jawad is requesting $3000 to buy a new large generator. He is aiming to expand his business so he will be able to improve his family’s quality of life.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Drocella

texts.en:
Drocella is 42 years old and married with five children between the ages of 8 and 22 years. Drocella sells bananas for a living. She has five years' experience in this business. 

Drocella has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more bananas to sell.  With the profits from this, Drocella will reinvest in her business and hopes to build a house of her own.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of bananas to sell.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en: Richel P.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. She is 33 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Resthouse, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Richel is just starting this business. In 2007, Richel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Richel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from GDMPC which was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Richel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use additional income to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. loans.name: Parachichi Group

texts.en:
Hilda B. is in her early thirties, married, and the mother of two children, one attending school and the other a baby. Hilda owns a cow whose milk she sells, a business she has operated since 2008. She works from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Hilda's fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to establish a chicken business and a pig business, neither of which succeeded. She then bought the cow for milk-selling. Having repaid all of her previous loans, she will use this one to repair an enclosure for pigs. Her dream is to one day have a big farm for a variety of animals.

Hilda will share this loan with her loan group "Parachichi" which has a total of 16 members. The group members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Hilda is second from the right in a blue and white dress.

loans.use: to repair an enclosure for pigs.

loans.name: Tomato Group

texts.en:
Yahaya N., is in his mid-forties and married, with two children who are still at school. He has been selling bricks for three years now.  He works from 9.00am to 6.00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Yahaya's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He hopes to buy more bricks to sell.  His dream is to one day open a hardware shop.

Yahaya will share this loan with his loan group "Tomato", which has a total of 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Yahaya is 1st on the left, 3rd row.

loans.use: to buy more bricks to sell.

loans.name: Lwazilwethu Group

texts.en:
Sibongelaphi is 45 years of age and married, with 4 children aged between 6 and 24 years. She runs a small business from her home in Mandini, South Africa (KZN).  She's wearing a cream white and peach shirt and also wearing a denim blue hat, standing in front of her group in the photo above. 

She has been in this business for 5 years. She has no other sources of income. She says that the main challenge to her business is the customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time.

She requested this loan from WDB and Kiva to buy cotton, wool, cold drinks, and breads. Extra income from this loan will help her pay her children's university education. In the future, she would like to have an art gallery. 

She adds that she is so grateful to WDB AND KIVA for giving her this loan. She also mentioned that she was just sitting back at home being helpless but WDB and KIVA rescued her.

loans.use: to buy cold drinks, breads and hand-crafts

loans.name: Jafred

texts.en:
Jafred is a farmer in Kitale town in Western Kenya and has been in  farming for 27 years. He is aged 60 and married, with 13 children between 26 and 4 years old, five of whom are still in school. His farm produces milk, maize, vegetables, fruits and eggs. He has employed one farmhand and sells his produce to the local market. 

Jafred has made a loan request of 62,400 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to pay for the purchase and insurance of a dairy cow. His says the milk produce will supplement the family meals and generate additional income to help him educate the remaining five children. He is focusing on having five cows of a better breed in the  future.

Jafred is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the loan facility but points out that the high cost of animal feeds during dry spells is a great challenge to the farming business.

loans.use: to pay for the purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Djelika

texts.fr:
Madame Djelika Koné est une femme mariée de 29 et mère de 4 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Massablacoura de Bougouni.
N’ayant pas fréquentée l’école moderne, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus. Elle exerça plusieurs activités mais sans réussite. Finalement c’est auprès de  son époux, qu’elle appris les activités d’achat et de vente de céréales. Depuis maintenant deux ans elle mène à son propre compte, son activité au marché Bougouni. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle et d'agrandir   son entreprise, elle décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso, pour acheter quelques tonnes de céréales (haricot, maïs, petit mil, arachide). Elle s’approvisionne à Bougouni et dans les villages environnants. Elle est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso. La vente se fait au marché de Bougouni.
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Ms. Djelika Koné is a 29-year-old married woman who has four children. She resides with her husband and children in the Massablacoura district of Bougouni. Not having attended school, she soon started working in revenue-generating businesses. She operated several business although unsuccessfully. In the end, she learned the business of buying and selling grains with the help of her husband. For two years now, she has been operating on her own at the Bougouni market.

Concerned about satisfying her customers and expanding her enterprise, Djelika decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to a few tonnes of grain (beans, corn, pearl millet, peanuts). She gets her supplies in Bougouni and in the surrounding villages. She is on her first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. Sales are made at the Bougouni market.

With this loan, Djelika plans on making a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan and to help her husband to cover family expenses. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy grains

loans.name: Abdrahamane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdrahamane F. est un homme marié de 35 ans et père de 2 enfants, qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez lui même à Bougouni, dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
Après des études secondaires sanctionnées par un diplôme en commerce et marketing, il est resté pendant des années sans emploi. C’est ainsi qu’après une longue réflexion il décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami des activités d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques.
Avec 6 ans d’expériences, il maitrise son activité d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques, dans laquelle il est très sollicité et apprécié.
C’est dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, qu’il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt diverses sortes de petits articles électroniques. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et effectue sa vente au marché de Bougouni et une partie dans les villages environnants les jours des marchés hebdomadaires. Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdrahamane F. is 35 years old, married, and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children in Bougouni, in the Hérémakono Nord neighborhood. After completing his studies and obtaining a diploma in business and marketing, he stayed unemployed for several years. After a long reflexion, he decided to learn buying and selling electronic devices with a friend.

Having six years of experience, he masters his business buying and selling electronic devices, and he is very much sought after and appreciated. In order to bolster his business, he decided to join Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which he is seeking his first loan.

He intends to use his loan to buy various small electronic items. He gets his supplies in Bamako, the capital of the Republic of Mali), and sells at the market in Bougouni, and in the surrounding villages on the day of the weekly fairs. He intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 35'000 (ca US$ 75), to be used to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy various small electronic devices

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Madame Adama Diakité est une femme mariée de 47 et mère de 3 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Dialanicoro de Bougouni.
N’ayant pas fréquentée l’école moderne, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus. Elle a tenté plusieurs activités notamment, la vente de chaussures et tissus, mais sans réussite.
Elle décida alors d’accompagner son oncle dans ses activités afin d’apprendre auprès de lui la vente de céréales. Avec une expérience de plus de 10 années, elle maîtrise son activité. Elle mène son activité dans le grand marché de Bougouni. Pour agrandir son entreprise, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter; 1 tonne de maïs, 2 tonnes de petit mil et 2 tonnes de riz...
Elle s’approvisionne à Bougouni et dans les villages  environnants. Il est à son troisième prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les prêts précédent ont été correctement remboursés
La vente se fait au grand marché de Bougouni et une partie est vendue dans les différents villages les jours de marchés hebdomadaires.
Avec ce prêt elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour agrandir davantage  son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adama Diakité, 47 years old, is married with three children. She lives with her husband and children in the Dialanicoro district of Bougouni.
Not having been able to attend a modern school, she quickly started earning a living. She has tried different business activities, such as selling shoes and fabrics, but without success.

Then she decided to join her uncle’s cereals business in order to learn from him. Now, with over 10 years experience, she excels at her work. She sells cereals at the big market of Bougoni. In order to expand her business she decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso in order to buy one ton [2200 lbs] of corn, two tons [4400 lbs] of millet and two tons [4400 lbs] of rice.

She stocks up in Bougoni and in the nearby villages. [She] is on her third loan with Soro Yiriwaso. All prior loans have been duly reimbursed. She sells at the big market of Bougouni, and partly also at weekly markets at different villages. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 60,000 West African francs, which will allow her to grow her business further

loans.use: to buy cereals

loans.name: Twekalangule Musoli Association Group

texts.en: 42 year-old Jesca T. operates a business selling fish from Musoli in the heart of Jinja. The mother of 10 has been engaged in this business for the past decade. Before this business, she was doing mostly farming.  She says hard work has gotten her this far.  She makes a profit from this business of Ugandan shillings 100,000 weekly.  With this loan, she says she is going to purchase more fish to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to resell

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Neang P. is a 42-year-old rice farmer who lives in the Ornlong Veng district of Siem Reap province. She is married to Kam Khim, age 46, who works with her in the farming business. Usually, the couple can generate around $6 each day for various family expenses. They have five single children; a few of them help with planting the rice crop and a few are studying in school. Due to the rainy season coming now, Neang P. would like to borrow a loan to purchase insecticides and potato seed for planting.

loans.use: to purchase insecticides and potato seed for planting.

loans.name: Thadee

texts.en:
Thadee B. is 44 years old and is married with five children between the ages 6 and 15 years old. 

He sells bananas in his business. Thadee has four year's experience and he employees two people to help him.

Thadee has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy more quantity of bananas to sell. With the profits, Thadee  will purchase a field and build his own house.

loans.use: To buy more quantity of bananas to sell.

loans.name: Sop Serigne Matar Sougou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Serigne Matar Sougou est créé le 9 avril 2011 jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois. Il est composé de 29 femmes qui sont des parentes et voisines elles habitent le même quartier et leur activité principale est le petit commerce. 

La responsable Fatou T. est mariée et a 4 enfants en charge; elle es âgée de 48 ans, elle est à droite sur la photo habillée en mauve et a croisé son bras sur son dos.

Elle mène une activité de petit commerce de denrées alimentaires et de vaisselles; elle fait parallèlement de l'embouche bovine et ovine ; elle a une bonne expérience dans ces domaines. Elle s'approvisionne dans les grandes villes surtout la capitale Dakar et revend ses produits( bols,assiettes,denrées alimentaires etc.) dans le village et les marchés hebdomadaires.

Son prêt lui permettra de renforcer la quantité et la qualité de son activité pour avoir plus de revenus. 

Elle aide le Chef de famille dans la prise en charge des dépenses quotidiennes et la nourriture des enfants.
texts.en:
The Sop Serigne Matar Sougou solidarity group was created on April 9, 2011, the day of the Banc Villageois inauguration. It is composed of 29 women who are relatives and neighbors. They live in the same neighborhood and all work as vendors. 

Fatou T., the group’s leader is married, with four dependent children. She is 48 years old. She is on the right on the photo wearing a mauve outfit and holding her arm behind her back. She sells groceries and tableware. In addition, she also raises cows and sheep. She has a good experience in these areas. She stocks up in big cities, especially in Dakar, the country’s capital, and resells her wares (bowls, plates, groceries etc) in her village and at the weekly market. Her loan will allow her to improve the quantity and quality of her stock in order to increase her revenues. She helps her husband provide for everyday expenses and food for their children.

loans.use: to buy groceries and tableware for resale

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David has been in farming for five years in his native town of Kitale in Western Kenya. He is married, with 4 children between 12 and 2 years, three of whom are in school. He has one farmhand and produces milk, maize, beans and poultry, which all go to the local market.

David has requested a loan of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the dairy cow will improve his milk production and provide income for his children's education, as well as acting as their food supplement. He is focusing on only high yield dairy cows for better output in the future.

David adds that Juhudi loans have helped in uplifting small farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bwera Group

texts.en: Forty-one-year-old W. Sarah has been operating her fresh fruit- and vegetable-selling business for the last 10 years. The mother of six operates from Jinja Central Market. Before she got involved in this business, she was working in a maize-milling factory. She says this business generates her 120,000 shillings as profit weekly. With this loan, she says she is going to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Sop Serigne Touba Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Serigne Touba est composé de 23 femmes. Elles habitent le même quartier. Le groupe est créé le 9 avril 2011, jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois de Ndieng D..

Soda N., la responsable du groupe, est âgée de 49 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants en charge. Elle est debout à l'extrême droite sur la photo et est emmitouflée d'une écharpe blanche.

Elle fait une activité de petit commerce d'huile d'arachide et de niébé (haricot local)Elle maitrise cette activité pour l'avoir pratiquée depuis plus de dix ans.

Son prêt lui permettra de financer son activité de petit commerce afin prétendre à plus de revenus.

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de besoins familiaux
texts.en:
The Sop Serigne Touba solidarity group is composed of 23 women. They all live in the same neighborhood. The group was created April 9th, 2011 - the same day the Ndieng D. "Banc Villageois" (loan group) was inaugurated.

Soda N., the group's leader, is 49 years old. She is married and the mother of eight dependent children. She is all the way to the right on the picture, and is wrapped in a white scarf.

She is active in the retail of peanut oil and niebe (a local bean). She has mastered this activity as a result of over ten years of experience.

Her loan will allow her to finance her retail activity to strive for greater income.

Her objective is to support her husband in providing for the family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase food products for resale

loans.name: Aitchedji Group

texts.fr: Le groupe AITCHEDJI est formé de cinq personnes qui habitent toutes dans le même quartier à Hindé dans la ville de Cotonou au Bénin. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Victoire Emilie, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Victoire Emilie est mariée à un imprimeur du nom de Wolgang. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à leur charge. Victoire Emilie habite le quartier Hindé à Cotonou depuis près de dix ans, où elle vit avec sa famille. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Il y a environs huit ans que Victoire Emilie mène comme activité la vente de tissus, des costumes et des sacs par le système de distribution. De façon secondaire, Victoire Emilie vend des produits vivriers. Victoire Emilie s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, et aussi à Cotonou. C’est la première fois que Victoire Emilie et son groupe sollicite de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur servira à renforcer leur activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
AITCHEDJI is a group composed of five people who all live in the same district in Hindé, in the city of Cotonou, in Benin. The representative of this group is named Victoire Emilie, and she is the one with her hand raised in the photo. Victoire Emilie is married to a printer named Wolgang. The couple has four children, who have all had schooling. Two of the children are in the couple’s care. Victoire has lived in the Hindé district in Cotonou for nearly ten years where she lives with her family. Together, the couple ensure that the various family expenses are covered.

For about eight years, Victoire has been running a business selling fabrics, suits, and handbags via the distribution system. On the side, she sells staple foods. She gets her supplies in Lomé, the capital of Togo, and also in Cotonou. This loan is the first one that she and her group have requested from ALIDé. The loan will be used to bolster their business in order to respond better to the demands of their customers.

loans.use: to buy cloth, suits, and handbags

loans.name: Wangnignigbe Group

texts.fr: Le groupe WANGNIGNIGBE est formé de trois  personnes qui résident toutes dans le même quartier à Sètovi à Cotonou (la capitale économique du Bénin). La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Philomène, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la cinquième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Philomène ne vit plus avec son mari, avec qui elle a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Depuis près de cinq ans, Philomène vit seule à Setovi avec un de ses enfants. Philomène n’est pas allée à l’école. Dans le but de subvenir à ses besoins et d’assurer l’éducation de son enfant, Philomène mène comme activité depuis huit ans environs, la vente de divers produits dont le riz, le haricot, les conserves, des savons et de la boisson locale, contrairement aux autres membres qui vendent des bois de chauffage. Philomène achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et les vend dans son quartier à Sètovi. Dans le but d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Philomène désire obtenir un autre crédit avec les autres membres de son groupe.
texts.en:
The WANGNIGNIGBE group is composed of three persons, who all reside in the same neighborhood, Setovi, in Cotonou (Benin's economic capital). The representative of the group, Philomene, is the woman raising her hand in the picture. It is the fifth time that this group is requesting ALIDe's financial support to increase their level of activity.

Philomene doesn't live with her husband anymore; she has three children with him, who all go to school. She has been living in Setovi, alone with one of her children, for five years. Philomene did not attend school.

In order to provide for her own needs and to guarantee that her child gets an education, Philomene has been active for about eight years in the retail of various products including rice, beans, canned food, soap and local beverages (the group's other members sell firewood). Philomene purchases her products in Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and sells them in her neighborhood of Setovi. To build up her product stock and better meet customer demand, Philomene wishes to be granted another loan with the other members of her group.

loans.use: to purchase rice, beans, canned food, soap, and local beverages

loans.name: Espoir Group

texts.fr: ESPOIR est un groupe constitué de trois personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a le doigt levé sur la photo) est nommée Mireille. Les membres du groupe résident dans la même zone géographique. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Née le 28 Décembre 1982 Cotonou (Bénin), Mireille vit depuis dix ans environs à Kindonou, un quartier de Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Mireille est mariée à revendeur du nom de Ganiou. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mireille assure ensemble avec son mari les différentes charges de la maison. Mireille a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, puis a appris la coiffure. Mireille exerce cette activité depuis six ans environs, ce qui lui permet d’assurer les besoins de sa famille. Parallèlement, Mireille vend des mèches, des tissus et des produits de beauté dans son atelier situé à Kindonou. Mireille achète ses  produits à Lomé au Togo. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Mireille et à son groupe de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
ESPOIR is a group made up of three people. The president (raising her finger in the photo) is called Mireille. The group members all live in the same area. With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group is asking for their first loan from ALIDé.
 
Mireille was born on December 28, 1982. For the last 10 years she has lived in Kindonou, a neighborhood of Cotonou (Benin's economic capital). Mireille is married to a wholesaler called Ganiou. They have two children, both of whom go to school. Together, Mireille and her husband are responsible for the household's various expenses. Mireille left school at the secondary level, then learnt to be a hairstylist. She has been doing this for about six years, which has allowed her to meet her family's needs. At the same time, Mireille sells hair extensions, fabric and beauty products in her shop located in Kindonou. She buys her products in  Lomé, Togo. This first loan will allow Mireille and her group to increase their level of activity, attract more clients and raise their income.

loans.use: to buy hair extensions, fabric and beauty products

loans.name: Maria Kpewu Group

texts.fr: MARIA KPEWU est un groupe constitué de cinq personnes dont la présidente (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo) se nomme  Prisque. Les membres du groupe appartiennent à un même groupe de tontine. Ce groupe sollicite un deuxième crédit en vue de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d'augmenter leur chiffre d'affaire. Née le 09 Janvier 1970 à Abomey dans le département du Zou, Prisque vit depuis trois ans à Vêdoko à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Prisque est mariée à Marc et à eu  deux  enfants, tous scolarisés. Prisque vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Prisque n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire, mais a appris la coiffure. Il y a environs trois ans que Prisque exerce cette activité, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. En dehors de cette profession qu’elle exerce, Prisque vend également des mèches, des produits de beauté et des cartes de recharges téléphoniques dans son atelier à Vêdoko. Prisque s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Prisque sollicite un financement auprès de ALIDé, afin d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire et son revenu.
texts.en: MARIA KPEWU is a group with five members. The President, Prisque has her finger raised in the photo.  The group members are all a part of the same tontine. They are asking for a second loan to enhance their business' activity and to increase their sales. Prisque was born on January 9, 1970 in Abomey, in the department of Zou. She has lived for three years now in Vedoko, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Prisque is married to Marc and they have two children who are in school. They all live together as a family. Together they are responsible for the various family expenses. Prisque only finished elementary school, but learned hairdressing. She has been in this business for about three years which has allowed her to provide for the needs of the family. As a side business, Prisque also sells hair extensions, beauty products and pay-per-use cellphone cards at her shop in Vedoko. She buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is asking for this loan from Alidé in order to grow her business and to grow her turnover and revenues.

loans.use: to purchase hair extensions, other beauty products and pay-per-use cellphone cards.

loans.name: Nazziba Central Women's Group

texts.en: Fifty-eight-year-old K. Felicity has been plying her poultry business for 15 years now. She operates her business from Nazziba neighborhood, which is a stone's throw away from Kampala, the capital of Uganda. The happily married mother of five comes across as a happy-go-lucky and hospitable lady. By her own account, it was not easy taking root in this business. She had no savings, owing to the fact that she had no job before. She says she owed it to herself to work diligently with a set objective of carving out her own niche in the poultry market, which in recent years has become highly lucrative. Apart from raising chickens, Felicity also sells eggs. She says this business generates her profits to the tune of 100,000 shillings weekly. She says with this loan money she is going to purchase more poultry to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more poultry to resell

loans.name: Dohami I Group

texts.fr: Le groupe "DOHAMI I" est formé de trois  personnes qui mènent toutes des activités similaires. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Pauline est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la troisième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Pauline est mariée à un certain Dominique. Le couple a quatre  enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois à leur charge. Pauline habite au quartier Vossa à Cotonou (Capitale économique du Bénin) avec ses enfants et son mari depuis huit ans. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Il y a près de cinq ans que Pauline mène comme activité, la vente de noix d’acajou à Cotonou. Pauline s’approvisionne à Agonli et à Dassa-Zoumé dans le Nord du Bénin. Dans le but d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Pauline désire obtenir un autre crédit avec les autres membres de son groupe.
texts.en: The "DOHAMI I" group has three members who all work in a similar business. The representative of the group, Pauline has her hand raised in the photo. This is the third time they are asking for a loan from Alidé with the intention of increasing their level of business activity. Pauline is married to Dominique, together they have four children who are all in school with three who are their dependents. They have lived together as a family in the Vossa neighborhood in Cotonou (economic capital of Benin) for eight years now. The couple is responsible together for all the family expenses. Pauline has been in the business of selling cashew nuts for almost five years in Cotonou. She buys her supplies in Agonli and Dassa-Zoumé in north Benin. With the goal to increase her inventory of cashew nuts and to better respond to her clients demand, Pauline is asking for another loan with the other members of her group.

loans.use: to purchase cashew nuts

loans.name: Calistus

texts.en:
Calistus is a resident and a farmer in the town of Kitale in western Kenya. He is age 37. Calistus is married and has four children between the ages of 2 and 11. He has been in mixed farming for over 10 years and has one farmhand. His farm produces milk, maize, beans, and poultry.

Calistus has made a loan request amounting to 62,400 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to help him purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will help him acquire the cow and improve his milk production capacity. He hopes to boost the family's living standard with the income. Calistus hopes to have acquired five dairy cows in five years' time. Calistus says dairy diseases and costly animal feeds are the main challenges in his farming business.

loans.use: to pay for the purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Tessito Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tessito est crée le 26 Mai 2001 et compte en son sein quinze femmes liées par une activités principale qui est le petit commerce. Elles ont une parfaite entente de par leur proximité d'habitat.

Sadio Sané debout à gauche de la photo et levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est agée de 79 ans. Elle est veuve et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a cinq autres personnes dont elle assure la charge.

Elle vend des légumes au marché de sa localité. Elle y dispose d'une étale qu'elle a occupé pendant 8 ans.

Avec ce crédit elle va augmenter son approvisionnement en légumes afin de faire croitre ses revenus financiers.

Son objectif est de subvenir à ses besoins personnels et à ceux des personnes en sa charge.
texts.en:
The Tessito group was founded on May 26, 2011. It has 15 women members who all work together for their small business. They understand each other well as they all live very close.

Sadio Sané, first of the left with her hand raised is in charge of the group. She is 79 years old. She is a widow and the mother of five children. She is also financially responsible for another five people.

She sells vegetables at the market in her village. She has been selling her goods from the same place for eight years.

With this loan she is going to increase her supply of vegetables in order to increase her revenues.

Her goal is to provide for her needs and those of her family.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables

loans.name: Medejro Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MEDEJRO est composé de trois personnes qui vivent toutes dans le même quartier à Kouhounou à Cotonou.  C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Jeanne est celle qui a le doigt levé sur la photo. Jeanne est née le 22 Août 1969 à Bohicon dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Jeanne est mariée à un pâtissier nommé Janvier et a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Jeanne et son mari assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Depuis près de quinze ans, Jeanne vit à Kouhounou avec son mari et ses enfants. Afin de se prendre en charge et d'améliorer son niveau de vie, Jeanne exerce depuis huit ans environs, comme activité la vente d’ustensiles de cuisine (assiettes, plastiques, etc.), qu'elle achète à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. De façon secondaire, Jeanne vend des tissus. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son revenu, Jeanne sollicite, ensemble avec son groupe, un autre crédit.
texts.en:
The MEDEJRO group is made up of three women from the same neighborhood of Kouhounou in Cotonou.  This is the second time that the group is seeking financial aid from ALIDé, with the goal of strengthening their business activities.  

The group's representative, Jeanne, is shown with her finger raised in the photo.  She was born on August 22, 1969, in Bohicon in the department of Zou in Benin.  Jeanne is married to a pastry chef named Janvier and has three children, all in school.  Jeanne and her husband share responsibility for the family’s expenses.  For about 15 years, Jeanne has lived in Kouhounou with her husband and children.  In order to support herself and improve her quality of life, for the past eight years she has been selling kitchen utensils (plates, plastic items, etc.), which she buys in Dantokpa, Benin's international market.  She also sells fabric on the side.  With the goal of satisfying her customers and to increase her income, Jeanne, together with her group, is requesting another loan.

loans.use:
Acheter des ustensiles de cuisine (assiettes, plastiques, etc.)
to buy kitchen utensils (plates, plastic items, etc.)

loans.name: Gbetodjin Enonmon Group

texts.fr: GBETODJIN ENONMON est un groupe constitué de trois personnes et dont la présidente (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo) est nommée Adjoavi. Les membres du groupe sont des amies et vivent ensemble dans la même zone à Sainte Rita à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin). Née le 27 Février en 1947 à Cotonou, Adjoavi habite le quartier Sainte Rita depuis deux ans. C’est une veuve ayant quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont encore à sa charge. Adjoavi  vit donc seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule leurs différentes charges.  Il y a quatre ans environs que Adjoavi fait le commerce de maïs et du riz à son domicile. Parallèlement, Adjoavi vend de la farine de manioc et des conserves. Cette activité lui procure des revenus l’aidant à assurer les différents besoins de ses enfants. Adjoavi se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Savalou dans le centre du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Adjoavi sollicite un financement auprès de ALIDé, afin d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire et son revenu.
texts.en:
GBETODJIN ENONMON is a group composed of three persons, including the president (with her finger raised in the photo) by the name of Adjoavi. The group members are friends, and they live together in the same area in Sainte Rita, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Born on February 27, 1947 in Cotonou, Adjoavi has lived in the Sainte Rita district for two years. She is a widow with four children, who have all had schooling. Two of the children are still in her care. She therefore lives alone with her children and covers their various expenses by herself. 

For about four years, Adjoavi has been doing commerce in corn and rice at her house. Concurrently, she sells cassava flour and some canned foods. This business brings in the revenues that help her to meet the different needs of her children. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and in the town of Savalou, in central Benin. This is the second time that she has requested financing from ALIDé in order to expand her business and increase her turnover, as well as her revenues.

loans.use: to buy corn, rice, cassava flour, and some canned foods

loans.name: Agneta

texts.en:
Agneta. age 36, is married with seven children between the ages of 1 and 18. She has been farming for five years in her hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya producing maize, beans and milk. All her produce is sold locally. Agneta fully relies on farming for her family's upkeep.

Agneta has requested a loan of 52,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She is optimistic that she will be able to make adequate income to provide for basic family needs like the provision of education and meals. However, Agneta laments of the high costs of animal diseases.

loans.use: to pay for the purchase and insurance of a dairy cow.

loans.name: Trinite Group

texts.fr: TRINITE est un groupe constitué de trois personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a le doigt levé sur la photo) est nommée Honorine Chadassi. Les membres du groupe se connaissent compte tenu du fait qu’ils habitent le même quartier à Gbèdégbé à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin). Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Née en 1940 à Abomey dans le département du Zou au Bénin, Honorine Chadassi vit depuis environs trois ans au quartier Gbèdégbé à Cotonou. Honorine Chadassi est une veuve ayant trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à sa charge. Honorine Chadassi vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs différents besoins. Honorine Chadassi n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Honorine Chadassi mène comme activité, la vente de maïs et de charbon de bois de façon secondaire dans son quartier. C’est à Glazoué au Sud du Bénin que Honorine Chadassi s’approvisionne.  Honorine Chadassi a déjà deux ans d’expérience dans l’exercice de cette activité.  Ce prêt permettra certainement à Honorine Chadassi et à son groupe de rehausser le niveau de leur activité par l’augmentation du stock de leurs produits et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en: “Trinity” is a group of three individuals, whose chair (the one giving the thumbs-up sign on the photo) is Honorine Chadassi. The group members know each other thfough being neighbors in the Gbèdégbé district of Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin). With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group is seeking a loan from ALIDé. Born in 1940 in Abomey, in the Zou Department of Benin, Honorine Chadassi has been living in the Gbèdégbé district of Cotonou for about three years.  She is a widow with three children, all of whom are in school, and two of whom are her dependents. Honorine lives by herself with her children, and alone provides for the family needs. Honorine  Chadassi never attended school. In order to support herself, Honorine Chadassi sells corn and also charcoal in her neighborhood. She stocks up in Glazoué in the south of Benin. She already has two years of experience in this line of work. This loan will certainly allow to Honorine Chadassi and her group to expand the business activities by enlarging their stock, in order to attract more customers and increase revenues.

loans.use: to buy corn and charcoal

loans.name: Shammah Group

texts.en: Nonhlanhla M. is the leader of Shammah Group. She is 33 years old and married with 3 children, aged 13, 11 and 8.  All of her children are attending school. Her business, which she has been running for 12 years, involves buying and selling cattle and chickens in Masvingo. In addition to operating this business, Nonhlanhla is a Civil Servant. The main challenge she faces is a lack of working capital. She has requested a loan of 400 USD through MicroKing to buy stock feed for her chickens. She plans to expand her business by purchasing more cattle to resell.

loans.use: to buy stock feed for her chickens

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.fr: Jean Baptiste N. R. est comptable, et client d’ACB depuis 2007.  Il a 49 ans, il est marie, et il a 3 enfants entre 7 ans et 14 ans, et aussi 2 personnes en charge.  Tous ses enfants vont à l’école.  Jean Baptiste est ne a Bukavu, en RDC, et il a fini ses études d’A0 dans le sujet d’accounting.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter les pneus et payer pour l’entretien de ses deux voitures (pour lui et pour sa femme).  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est de travailler beaucoup dans son boulot de comptable, et renforcer le business de sa femme, qui est commerçante.  Dans l’avenir, il voudrait construire une autre maison à louer pour augmenter ses revenues.  Pour sa famille, il voudrait éduquer ses enfants.
texts.en: Jean Baptiste N. R. is an accountant, and has been a customer of ACB since 2007. He is 49, married, has 3 children between the ages of 7 and 14, and takes care of 2 other people. All his children go to school. Jean Baptiste was born in Bukavu, DRC, and he holds a A0 level diploma in accounting. He will use this loan to buy new tires and pay for car servicing (his own car and his wife's). His strategy for the growth of his business is to work hard as an accountant and strengthen the business of his wife, who is a storekeeper. In the future, he would like to build another house he would rent to increase his income. For his family, he would like his children to have an education.

loans.use: to buy tires and pay for car servicing (his car and his wife's)

loans.name: Nonvignon Vedoko Group

texts.fr: NONVIGNON VEDOKO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres vivent ensemble dans le même quartier  à Vêdoko à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin). La présidente du groupe, Laure (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo), est née en 1977 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Laure est mariée à un hôtelier du nom de Hlouédé. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à leur charge. Il y a près de quatre ans que Laure vit au quartier Vêdoko avec sa famille. Laure est allée à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire, puis a appris la couture. C’est cette activité que Laure exerce depuis trois ans et qui lui permet de nourrir sa famille et de satisfaire ses besoins. De façon secondaire, Laure vend de la farine de manioc, du sucre et des fournitures de couture dans son atelier. Laure achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Laure sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui permettra de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en: NONVIGNON VEDOKO is a group of 3 people who all live in Vêdoko, a neighborhood of Cotonou (economic capital of Bénin). The president of the group, Laure (whom you can see raising her hand on the picture), was born in 1977 in Ouidah, a historical city of Bénin. Laure is married to a hotelier named Hlouédé. They have 3 children who all go to school. Two of them live with them. Laure has been living in the Vêdoko nieghborhood with her family for about 4 years. She went to school up to the secondary level and then went on to learn sewing. With the job she has had for 3 years, Laure has been able to feed and cater to her family. On the side, Laure also sells cassava, sugar, and sewing supplies in her workshop. She buys those items from Dantokpa, an international market in Bénin. This is the second time that Laure is asking for a loan from ALIDé. It will enable her to strengthen her business and to better meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: to buy sewing supplies, fabric, etc.

loans.name: Thuthukani Group

texts.en:
Thenjiswa is 53 years old and single, with five children between the ages of 2 and 38. Two of them attend school. She also cares for one additional relative. She runs a retail business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Emandeni, South Africa. In the photo she is standing on the far right wearing a white hat.

She's been in this business for three years, selling fruits and vegetables in the mall. She also receives income from the government's children's grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time, because that will delay her profit.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy face cloths, table cloths, fruits and vegetables. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to the higher educational institutions and build a house for her family. In future she would like to own a fruit and vegetable market and a small farm where she can do her planting. 

In her comments, she adds that WDB and Kiva have been a help to them because she does not qualify for a loan from banks.

loans.use: to buy face cloths, table cloths, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: John A.s.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers from the Benevolent Islamic Primary School, Magburaka.  This school was built by the Benevolent Mission in 1982. It has a total of 20 staff and 656 pupils.

This group of teachers has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 13,000,000 SLL. With the help of this loan, some of these teachers will start a small business and those who are already running small businesses will invest the loan into their business. Some of the staff members will be using the loan to buy pieces of furniture, others to pay either for their children's education or for themselves to pursue further studies. Others will use their loan in home building projects. With their monthly salaries, they will gradually repay their loan to SMT. 

John A.S. K. is the Deputy Head Teacher at the school. The 40-year-old has been in the teaching profession for eleven years now. John is married to a businesswoman and the two of them have four children together. With this loan, John will buy house equipment like a refrigerator and a generator.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and a generator.

loans.name: Jehovah Chama Group

texts.fr: Le groupe JEHOVAH CHAMA est composé de trois personnes qui vivent toutes dans la même zone géographique à sainte Rita à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin). Ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Monique est celle qui a le doigt levé sur la photo. Monique est née en Mai 1966 à Porto-Novo et est marié à un enseignant nommé Cosme. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Monique et son mari assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Il y a près de six ans, Monique vit à Sainte Rita avec son mari et ses enfants. Afin de se prendre en charge et d'améliorer son niveau de vie, Monique exerce depuis quatre ans, comme activité la vente de friperies dans son quartier. Monique achète ses friperies à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son revenu, Monique sollicite à nouveau un crédit.
texts.en: The Jehovah Chama group is made up of three people who all live in the same geographical area of Sainte Rita, Cotonou (Benin's economic capital). This group is requesting financial help from Alidé in order to increase the level of their activities. The group's representative, Monique, is the one raising her finger in the photo. She was born in May 1966 in Porto-Novo and is married to a teacher named Cosme. The couple has two children, both at school. Monique and her husband cover the various family expenses between them. She has lived in Sainte Rita with her husband and children for almost six years. In order to take responsibility for and improve her living conditions, Monique has for the past four years been selling second-hand clothes in her neighborhood. She buys her second-hand clothes in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She is requesting another loan with a view to satisfying customer demand and increasing her income.

loans.use: to purchase second-hand clothing

loans.name: Fidelina

texts.es: Fidelina de cuarenta y tres años de edad vive en casa propia con su familia. Ella se dedica a la venta de artículos de uso personal, perfumes y cosméticos, en un puesto ubicado en un centro comercial muy popular en en la ciudad en que vive, el lugar es muy concurrido por las personas del lugar y es así como Fidelina se ha hecho de mucha clientela, ella es muy servicial con las personas que la visitan además siempre tiene lo que necesitan y lo vende a un precio accesible. Fidelina piensa que el camino al éxito en su negocio está en el esfuerzo de su trabajo y quiere verlo crecer es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le dé la oportunidad de comprar perfumes, cosméticos, esmaltes, y otros artículos de uso personal. Fidelina tiene fe que su trabajo le permitirá  llevar a su hogar una condición de vida más favorable.
texts.en:
Fidelina is 43 years old and lives in her own home with her family.  She sells personal use products, perfumes, and cosmetics at a stand in the central market within the city where she lives.  This busy place is full of people, which explains why Fidelina has many customers.  She is very helpful to the customers who visit her.  Fidelina always has what they need and sells her products at an affordable price.  She believes that the road to success for her business requires effort in her work. 

In order to grow her business, she is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral so that she can buy perfumes, cosmetics, nail polishes, and other products for personal use.  Fidelina has faith that her work can help her provide more favorable living conditions for her home.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, cosmetics, nail polishes, and other products for personal use.

loans.name: María Esperanza

texts.es:
María Esperanza de 53 años de edad, reside en casa propia con su compañero de vida, tres hijos y dos nietos. Doña María es una mujer increíble y ejemplar ya que ha trabajado y sigue trabajando duramente para ayudar con la economía de su hogar y dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. Ella posee un puesto de tortillas y a la vez tiene una pequeña tiendita en donde ofrece diferentes productos de primera necesidad. Los clientes la prefieren por su amabilidad y buen servicio y esto ha hecho que su clientela aumente. Ella es una mujer emprendedora y a pesar de su avanzada edad no se da por vencida. 

Su sueño es mejorar la calidad de vida de sus seres queridos y para ello necesita más ingresos  es por esta razón que ha decidido solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL que le permita comprar lo necesario para mantener surtida su tienda con diferentes artículos como aceite, arroz, azúcar, frijoles, sal, café y maíz para  tener las ricas tortillas a la hora. Con esto espera obtener mayores ganancias para seguir ayudando a su familia.
texts.en:
María Esperanza is 53 years old and resides in her own home with her life partner, her three children, and two grandchildren.  Doña María is an incredible woman and an example of how hard work can help with the household finances and provide one’s family with a better quality of life.  She has a tortilla stand and a small store where she offers basic necessities.  Her customers prefer to do business with her because of her friendliness and good service.  As a result, her clientele has grown.  María is an enterprising woman and has no plans of quitting despite her age.  

Her dream is to improve the quality of life of her loved ones.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral so that she can buy what she needs to restock her store such as oil, rice, sugar, beans, salt, coffee, as well as corn for making her delicious tortillas.  With this assistance, she hopes to generate more income so that she can continue supporting her family.

loans.use: to purchase corn for making tortillas and merchandise for her grocery store.

loans.name: Eliezer Group

texts.en: Revai M. is the leader of the Eliezer Group. She is 39 years old and single, with two children, ages 10 and 9. Both of the children are attending school. Her business includes the buying and selling of livestock as well as clothes in Masvingo. She has been running this business for ten years. In addition to her business, Revai is a school teacher. Her main challenge is the stiff competition she faces, which at times affects the price of her merchandise. Revai requested this loan through MicroKing for $400 to buy clothes to resell. She plans to open a boutique in Masvingo in the near future.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Horacio

texts.es: Horacio, tiene 57 años de edad, vive en casa propia con su compañera de vida y dos hijos que se encuentran estudiando. Don Horacio es transportista realiza viajes de pasajeros y de materiales de construcción como arena, madera, etc.  a la capital del país. Él posee un pick up que es su herramienta fundamental para la realización de su trabajo. Es muy conocido en la zona y muchas personas solicitan su servicio ya que saben que es un hombre responsable, amable y serio en su trabajo,  esto ha hecho que muchas personas soliciten sus servicios, lo que ha llevado a un deterioro normal de su vehículo, es por esta razón que se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL para  darle mantenimiento y reparar su herramienta de trabajo, y de esta manera  poder dar el servicio seguro que el cliente se merece. Con el crédito piensa invertir en llantas, frenos, pintura, batería, y otros que son indispensables para que  su pick up pueda seguir funcionando de manera segura. De esta forma el podría prestar un mejor servicio y los clientes estarían más satisfechos con él y lo solicitarían más. Esto daría como resultado mayores ingresos que le servirían para seguir dando a su familia el pan de cada día.
texts.en:
Horacio Ramo is 57 years old and lives with his life partner and their two children who are in school.  Don Horacio is a carrier who transports passengers and construction materials such as sand, wood, and other products.  He travels to the capital of San Salvador.  Horacio owns a pickup truck, which is the main piece of equipment that he uses for his work.  He is well-known in the area and many people request his service because they know he is a responsible man who is friendly and serious about his business.  

Horacio decided to request a loan from Apoyo Integral in order to maintain and repair his vehicle so that he can provide the safe service that his customers deserve.  With this loan he will invest in tires, brakes, paint, batteries, and other supplies that are essential in making sure that his pickup continues to function properly.  This will enable him to provide the best service so that his customers stay satisfied and continue to do business with him.  Horacio hopes this will result in more income so that he can continue providing for his family’s daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for maintaining and repairing his pickup truck.

loans.name: José Roberto

texts.es:
José Roberto, habita  en casa propia con su esposa y tres hijos que son lo más importante para él. José se dedica a la venta de ropa tanto para hombre como para mujer. Debido a que no posee un lugar fijo para  realizar la venta lo hace de manera ambulante. Ha trabajado durante mucho tiempo de esta forma y le ha dado buenos resultados. Cada día sale muy temprano de su casa para realizar sus ventas en las diferentes zonas cercanas al lugar en que vive, es muy conocido y muchas personas lo prefieren ya que siempre cuenta con variedad, nuevos y diferentes estilos de prendas de vestir. 

Su sueño es poder seguir ayudando a su familia a salir adelante. Esto lo ha impulsado a solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL  con la esperanza que de esta forma logrará cumplir su sueño. Con el crédito pretende comprar variedad de pantalones tanto para hombre como para mujer, blusas, camisetas, faldas, shorts, y nuevos estilos que sean atractivos para los clientes ya que de la demanda de estos depende el éxito del negocio. Con esto espera lograr aumentar sus ventas para dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
José Roberto lives in his own home with his wife and three children who are most important to him.  He sells clothes for men and women.  Since he does not have an established vending location, José sells his products as a traveling merchant.  He has worked in this manner for a long time and has achieved good results.  Each morning he leaves his house very early so that he can sell in different areas of the city where he lives.  José is well-known and many people prefer to buy from him because he always has a variety of clothes in new and different styles.  

His dream is to continue helping his family move forward.  This prompted him to request a loan from Apoyo Integral in hopes to being able to fulfill this dream.  He intends to use the funds to buy a variety of men’s and women’s trousers, blouses, T-shirts, skirts, shorts, and new styles of clothing that are popular with his customers since the demand for these products will determine the success of his business.  José hopes to increase his sales so that he can provide his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase various articles of clothing for men and women.

loans.name: Rosa Hilda De Jesús

texts.es:
Rosa Hilda, de 64 años de edad, reside en casa propia con su hijo y un nieto. Doña Rosa se dedica a la venta de bebidas como sodas, agua, jugos, té, etc. Estas ventas las realiza de manera ambulante en lugares estratégicos de la zona. Ella se mantiene bien informada de las diferentes actividades que se realizan en los alrededores de su residencia ya que aprovecha los días festivos y sus celebraciòn para realizar su venta. Es una mujer llena de energía y no duda en ir a los diferentes lugares en los que hay fiestas, ferias, partidos de futbol, conciertos etc. Ya que es ahí en donde sus ventas se ven incrementadas. 

Como toda mujer emprendedora quiere aumentar el nivel de ventas para esto necesita tener variedad de bebidas para ofrecer a sus clientes en los diferentes eventos a los que asiste. Esto la ha impulsado a solicitar este crédito para poder lograr comprar variedad de bebidas como: sodas, jugos, agua, té helados y de más bebidas que sean demandadas por los clientes.  De esta forma espera obtener mayores ganancias que le ayuden a mejor su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa Hilda is 64 years old and resides in her own home with her son and grandson.  Doña Rosa has a business selling beverages such as sodas, water, juices, tea, and others.  She sells as a street vendor from strategic locations within the area.  Rosa is well-informed about different events that take place near her home, so she takes advantage of these festival days to generate sales.  She is full of energy and does not hesitate to travel to different places where festivals, fairs, soccer games, concerts, and other events are taking place so that she can set up her business.  As a result, her sales have increased.  

Being an enterprising woman, Rosa wants to increase her level of sales.  For this reason, she needs to have a variety of beverages to offer to her customers at different events they attend.  This led her to request a loan so that she can buy a variety of beverages such as sodas, juices, water, iced teas, and other drinks that are in demand among her customers.  By working in this manner, she hopes to generate more income to help improve her quality of life and that of her family.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of beverages to sell.

loans.name: Videkon Group

texts.fr: Le groupement VIDEKON est composé de trente membres qui se connaissent parce qu’elles habitent dans le même quartier à Womey dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. La présidente de ce groupement, du nom de Elisabeth, est celle ayant une main levée sur la photo. Dans le but de rehausser le niveau de leur activité afin de mieux faire face à la demande de leur clientèle, ce groupement sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé. Elisabeth est mariée à un agent au Port nommé Robert et a trois enfants à charge, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont ses propres enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Il y a environs cinq ans que Elisabeth et son mari se sont installés à Womey. Elisabeth n’est jamais allée à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Elisabeth mène comme activité depuis quatre ans environs, la vente de friperies de façon ambulante. C'est au marché de Missèbo à Cotonou que Elisabeth s'approvisionne. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Elisabeth sollicite avec les autres membres de son groupe, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Son ambition est d’accroître le niveau de son activité.
texts.en: The Videkon group is composed of 30 members who know each other through being neighbors from the same district of Womey, in the community of Abomey Calavi. The group’s leader, by the name of Elisabeth, it the one raising her hand in the photo. With the goal of expanding their business and better meeting customer demand, the group is asking for financing from ALIDé. Elisabeth is married to Robert, a port agent, and has three dependent children, two of whom are her own, and all of whom are in school,. The spouses jointly take care of various family expenses. Elisabeth and her husband settled in Womey about five years ago. Elisabeth never attended school. In order to support herself and her family, she has been selling second-hand clothing as a street vendor for about four years. She stocks up at the Missèbo market in Cotonou. In order to strengthen her business and better meet her customers’ needs, Elisabeth and her group are seeking a loan from ALIDé. She would like to expand the scope of her business.

loans.use: to buy some bales of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Chernor's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you teachers from the TDEC Primary School, located in Magbass village, near Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. TDEC was founded in 1993 by the Tonkolili District Council to help educate the people of Magbass village. Currently, the school has a staff of 16 dedicated teachers and an enrollment of 405 pupils. 

Chernor B. is a teacher at the school and the leader of this group of borrowers. 48-year-old Chernor has been in the teaching profession for twenty-five years now. A native of Magbass village, Chernor is married to a businesswoman and the couple has four children – three in primary school and one in secondary school. Chernor has requested this loan in order to buy agricultural seeds and to pay laborers to plant his farm. 

Staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment, and pays SMT on their behalf.

loans.use: to buy agricultural seeds and pay laborers to plant his farm.

loans.name: Twezimbe Development Kasenge-Kampala Group

texts.en: Clothing sales is 36-year-old N. Sarah's enterprise. It has been her source of livelihood for the last three years. The hardworking, courteous and good-natured mother of six began this enterprise under the financial auspices of her husband. Prior to that, she was a housewife. Weekly, Sarah says her profits amount to approximately $42, and she says that with this loan, she is going to purchase more bales of clothing to resell. In the group photo, Sarah's face is only partially seen, as another client unwittingly covered part of her face. For that reason I have marked her as unpictured.

loans.use: to purchase more bales of clothes to resell.
